thread.title: LaDainian Tomlinson, Kurt Warner make Hall of Fame; Terrell Owens denied
thread.title_full: LaDainian Tomlinson, Kurt Warner make Hall of Fame; Terrell Owens denied

author: Ron Clements (us-editorial@performgroup.com)
title: LaDainian Tomlinson, Kurt Warner make Hall of Fame; Terrell Owens denied
text:
NFL February 4, 2017 8:23pm EST February 4, 2017 8:21pm EST American Football, News, English, LaDainian Tomlinson, Brian Dawkins, NFL, Buffalo Bills, Dallas Cowboys, Denver Broncos, Philadelphia Eagles, San Diego Chargers, San Francisco 49ers, Seattle Seahawks, St. Louis Rams, Tampa Bay Buccaneers Warner, LT and TD are joined by Jason Taylor, Morten Andersen, Kenny Easley and Jerry Jones in the 2017 Pro Football Hall of Fame class. LaDainian Tomlinson (Getty Images) 
Updated at 8:23 p.m. ET 
Updated at 8:23 p.m. ET 
Terrell Owens will have to wait another year. 
Owens was not elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in his second year of eligibility. 
While Owens did not get in, former Chargers running back LaDainian Tomlinson headlines the 2017 Hall of Fame class. Former Rams and Cardinals quarterback Kurt Warner will join Tomlinson for enshrinement in Canton, Ohio on Aug. 5, along with former Dolphins pass rusher Jason Taylor, former Broncos running back Terrell Davis, former Saints and Falcons kicker Morten Andersen and former Seahawks safety Kenny Easley. Cowboys owner Jerry Jones was also elected to the Hall of Fame as a contributor. 
MORE: Looking back at the 2016 Hall of Fame class 
Andersen, the NFL's all-time scoring leader, joins Jan Stenerud as the only true kickers in the Hall. Andersen successfully converted 565 field goals and missed just 10 extra points in 859 attempts in his 25-year career. 
Tomlinson is the Chargers' all-time leading rusher, and ranks fifth on the NFL's all-time list with 13,684 yards. He and Taylor, who retired in 2011 with 139 1/2 sacks and 40 forced fumbles, were elected in their first year of eligibility. The only other finalist in his first year of eligibility was former Eagles and Broncos safety Brian Dawkins. 
Warner, who was named NFL MVP in 1999 and 2001, helped the Rams win Super Bowl XXXIV. He went back to the Super Bowl with the Cardinals in 2008. Warner's 208 career touchdown passes ties him with Jay Cutler and Kerry Collins for 35th all-time. But his 93.7 career passer rating is 10th all-time. 
Davis was voted into the Hall despite playing just seven years and only three Pro Bowl selections. While his career was short and he had just three seasons of high productivity, those three seasons were deemed great enough to get him into the Hall. David was the NFL MVP in 2008 after rushing for 2,008 yards and helping the Broncos win Super Bowl XXXIII. He was the MVP of Super Bowl XXXII as he ran for 157 yards and three touchdowns in a 31-24 win over the Packers. 
Like Davis, Easley had just a seven-year career, but was a five-time Pro Bowler and the NFL's Defensive Player of the Year in 1984, when he had 10 of his 32 career interceptions. Easley was also the 1981 AFC Defensive Rookie of the Year. 
Since Jones bought the Cowboys in 1989, they have reached the playoffs 14 times and won three Super Bowl titles. Read This
